_chemical.ChemicalName: Oleum (Fuming Sulfuric acid)  [Sulfuric acid, mixture with sulfur trioxide]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. is a chemical distributor serving the areas of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, New York, Washington DC, Maryland and Virginia.  In this capacity, Coyne is a re-seller of chemicals to industrial, commercial and municipal customers.  Of the current inventory consisting of approximately 200 types of chemicals, three are considered extraordinarily hazardous under the RMP regulations and are stored above the applicable threshold value.  The facility is located on 8.393 acres within the Edgely Industrial Park and is bordered by a rail siding to the North, a water retention basin on the East, State Road to the South and Westrock to the West.



The three chemicals on site subject to RMP regulations are:



Chlorine (CAS # 7782-50-5)

Sulfur Dioxide (CAS # 7746-09-5)

Oleum - 20% (CAS # 8014-95-7)



Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are also subject to the OSHA PSM regulations (29 CFR 1910.119)



Stationary Source Identification



Coyne Chemical has identified the storage of the reference materials as the only stationary source at the facility.  



Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are both contained within pre-packaged cylinders containing 150 lbs. of product each.  All full cylinders are stored inside dedicated storage rooms within the warehouse in storage racks with 16 cylinders per rack. The worst-case release scenario at the facility is a full cylinder release of a sulfur dioxide cylinder occurring outside of the facility during the unloading process. This scenario does not take into account any of the passive mitigating systems built into the storage process.   Due to the fact that that the sulfur dioxide and chlorine cylinders are stored in storage racks designed to house this type of cylinder and transported in the storage racks or individually secured within the transportation vehicle, and the loading and unloading step is the shortest step of the process, the worst-case scenario is not likely to occur.



Oleum is transferred from ta

nk trucks which are considered in transportation, to 55-gal drums and stored onsite prior to shipment. 



Emergency Response



Coyne Chemical has an in-house Emergency Response Team trained to handle potential emergencies involving the registered chemicals.  In addition to the in-house emergency response team, a manager can be reached via the emergency voice mail system whenever the facility is closed in order to organize an emergency response. Coyne has arrangements with outside emergency response personnel to supplement as needed. The emergency response plan will be coordinated with the County Office of Emergency Management (OEM).



It is the policy of the George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. to have programs in place to identify and handle emergency response and public preparedness issues involving products handled at facilities operated by the company, in transit, and during storage and/or use at a customer's site. These programs address the following items deemed critical to achieving this goal:



A.    Documentation, review, coordination and tests of emergency response plans.

B.    Procedures for response, reporting, investigation and implementation of preventative measures with respect to incidents which could have or did result in a release, explosion and/or fire.

C.    Procedures for supplying emergency response information regarding chemicals handled to emergency response agencies and communication with state and local emergency planning and response organizations regarding potential hazards of products handled at facilities.



Security



An (8) eight-foot tall chain link fence equipped with barbed wire around the top protects the outside boundary of Coyne Chemical.  The Northeast gate serves as the main entrance for all traffic.  This gate is electrically controlled and cannot be opened from the outside without a pass card and remains closed at all times.  The gate on the South side is kept locked at all times but can be unlocked and opened if evacuation thr

ough that gate is necessary.



Overhead light standards are located on the exterior perimeter of the plant property as well as positioned along the top of the building to illuminate all exterior areas of the property. All entries to the office and warehouse are secured and monitored by an alarm system.  Movement through the facility is further managed utilizing a key pass system.  In the event of an unauthorized entrance, an alarm is sounded at a central monitoring station, the local police department is dispatched, and a Coyne Chemical manager is notified.





Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical Specific Prevention Procedures



Mitigation for Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide scenarios includes applying a cylinder "A" Kit or placing the leaking cylinder into a containment vessel located on-site.  Leaking drums can be contained in secondary containment. 



The chlorine and sulfur dioxide are stored in chemical specific rooms within the warehouse.  These rooms have product-specific detectors with alarms that will trigger in the event of a leak from a cylinder. These alarms trigger a number of passive systems to minimize a release. Coyne utilizes frequent visual inspection to determine the presence of a leak.



Coyne Chemical is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD) and subscribes to its Responsible Distribution Processes.  As part of this process, Coyne Chemical has developed policies and procedures regarding Risk Management, Emergency Response and Security.



It is the policy of the George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. to have programs in place to promote the process of risk assessment and management in relation to the chemicals and services provided by the Company. These programs address the primary goal of continual risk reduction by analysis of the hazards of the chemicals distributed, the likelihood of accidents/incidents, and the impact of these releases on the public and the environment.  The Company fully supports and encour

ages employee participation in the safety programs established and requires strict adherence to the guidelines established for the safe operation of its facilities.



Continuous risk reduction will be encouraged through the following steps:



A. Product review and hazard assessment,

B. Hazard ranking of the chemicals distributed,

C. Review with Manufacturer of products supplied,

D. Incident review and analysis, and

E. Employee training



5 Year Accident History



There have been no on-site releases of these chemicals within the last 5 years.  





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Coyne Chemical has completed a Process Hazard Analysis with risk assessment for the registered chemicals.  Coyne has identified the hazards of working with the extraordinarily hazardous substances on site and has developed programs and systems to safeguard against those hazards.  These procedures are subject to a management of change procedure, which allows the facility management to review and upgrade procedures and programs when necessary.  Coyne will continue to review the procedures and implement protective solutions to health and safety concerns.  There are no additional planned changes to improve safety associated with the handling of extraordinarily hazardous substances at this time.
